The fourth masterpiece in a row from a studio that seems to not know how to make a mistake. This one is a roguelite set in the Underworld, Hades, and has you assume the role of Hades' rather wilful son Zagreus who has set his mind on escaping to the surface. He has allies both above and below, as he is aided by his adoptive mother Nyx, as well as a complement of Olympian gods. Primordial Chaos lends a hand here and there as well.
Visually, Hades is what I've come to expect from Supergiant: vibrant, gaudy colours, a stubbornly specific style, and lots of contrast. The sound design is cool as well, the music is superb.
Since Hades is a roguelite, it expects you to navigate its environs with the utmost precision and power. It happily provides you a bunch of tools to do this very thing. You have 8 weapons at your disposal, different aspects of each can be unlocked a bit later into the game. The hidden aspects are fun callouts of different mythologies. The abovementioned Olympians grant you boons as you go through levels, each of which functions as an upgrade in the spirit of its giver. The boons are almost entirely random, meaning that you will go through quite a few runs before coming across a playstyle you've experienced before. This, and a bunch of mechanics meant to provide further difficulty give Hades a very high replayability value (within one save game, if that makes sense).
The only problem I have with it is that it asks too much - it is too difficult for me. Thankfully, the developers have included the aptly named God Mode which provides the player with damage resistance which increases with deaths.
TLDR awesome game, as usual. Get it.

A Masterpiece of Roguelike Design

Hades is nothing short of phenomenal. From its gripping narrative to its meticulously crafted gameplay, this game has it all. The blend of fast-paced combat, strategic depth, and rich storytelling creates an experience that‚Äôs both addictive and rewarding.

Pros:

Engaging Combat: The combat is fluid and satisfying, with a wide variety of weapons and abilities that keep each run fresh and exciting. The skill ceiling is high, but the game offers plenty of tools and upgrades to help you improve.

Fantastic Art and Music: The visual style is stunning, with vibrant, detailed environments and character designs. The soundtrack is equally impressive, perfectly complementing the action and mood.

Deep Storytelling: The narrative is woven into the gameplay seamlessly. The characters are well-developed, and their interactions are both entertaining and meaningful. It‚Äôs rare to see a roguelike that invests so much in its story, and Hades excels in this regard.

Replayability: Each run feels different thanks to the diverse range of upgrades and choices. The game‚Äôs progression system keeps you coming back for more, with plenty of unlocks and secrets to discover.

Quality of Life: The game offers a range of accessibility options and thoughtful design choices that make the experience smooth and enjoyable.

Cons:

Challenging for Some: The difficulty can be quite steep, especially for those new to roguelikes. However, the game‚Äôs gradual learning curve and abundant resources help mitigate this.
Overall, Hades is a triumph in game design. It manages to combine intense gameplay with a rich narrative, making every escape attempt feel meaningful. Whether you‚Äôre a roguelike veteran or a newcomer, this game is an absolute must-play. Highly recommended!

Despite the unanimous praise for this game and all those unexpected wins in the 2020 game awards, I didn't play Hades until this year. It wasn't the type of game I had tried before, nevertheless it was on my radar.

Character design + choice of colours was right up my alley.

The characters are all loveable. Especially, Thanatos. If I had a nickel for every time I crushed on Thanatos in any piece of media, I'd have two nickels. Which isn't a lot, but it's weird that it happened twice.

Dialogues were enjoyable, some were witty, some were heartfelt; The whole dialogue system made it feel like a lot of care had been put into planning it. Always looked forward to what each character would say after doing a specific thing.

The soundtrack was great, the vibes were immaculate.

Since it's a roguelite game, there's a lot of grinding to do. The last time I grinded this much in a videogame was back when I played Yakuza 0. So unless you are used to roguelite games and don't mind grinding to progress in the story and character relationships, it might not be your cup of tea.

Overall, a great game

I am impressed. I don't have a huge amount of fanaticism for 3rdP action games and liked Bastion alright but that was it. 

Hades is next level. It's got that Binding of Isaac gameflow but with a super tight, well balanced action combat that feels like how I hear people hype up Devil May Cry, but with a perspective that actually makes it possible to see what's going on. I don't exactly know what it was, I'm sure it was many small things, but they have absolutely NAILED the gamefeel in this game. I'm very excited to pick up the currently EA sequal now just to see more weapons, more enemy types, new boons and such. Some how the engine they've made here makes essentially any variation feel extremely nice so my only critique is... gimme more!

The game itself is good, but the narrative choices are superb including next level character designs of tried and true god characters seen in a new, but still extremely accurate, light. I suspected that they were going to over-modernize the characters, and have writing like something along the lines of Night in the Woods where it sounds like you're reading some college student's twitter feed, but it's not like that at ALL. This is now one of my big inspirations for character writing. They all have super unique voices and their motivations are made totally obvious, all without even a directly linear plot. The devs have made an amazing system where you get relevant dialogue based on your recent in-game actions from a myriad of characters, and I struggle to think of a game that pulled off a more organic, non-linear storytelling technique that's this effective because of it. 

I am blown away, and made all the better by it's excellent Steam Deck performance, including good battery usage and clear sound mixing for smaller speakers, which you don't always find with a kick-ass game. 

STRONG recommend!
